DOC.HEAD: Boeing Engineers Reject Contract, Technicians Approve Theirs
DOC.TEXT: Boeing Co. engineers and scientists rejected a three-year contract with the world's largest commercial jet builder but technicians and support workers ratified a separate pact, union leaders said Monday night. Charles Bofferding, president of the Seattle Professional Engineering Employees Association, said members of the professional unit voted by 69 percent to reject their contract offer but also voted 52 percent against authorizing negotiators to call a strike. It was the first time in the unaffiliated union's history that engineers and scientists rejected a contract offer, he said. The union consists of nearly 9,300 of 15,200 affected Boeing scientists and engineers. About 8,300 of Boeing's nearly 12,800 technical and support workers belong to the technical workers unit. Almost all of those covered by both contracts are in the Puget Sound area. Leaders of the engineers union will contact Boeing officials immediately about returning to the table, Bofferding said. ``We are critical parts of the Boeing team, and we affect them in all areas,'' he said. Bofferding said the voting rate for both units exceeded 80 percent, a record. The unions vote by mail. The offers included general pay hikes totaling 3 percent for engineers and 7 percent for the lower-paid technicians. Bofferding said he believed the main factor in the engineers' rejection was the belief that the money package was too small compared with that won by Boeing production workers in a 48-day strike that ended last month. The Machinists' three-year pact includes pay increases of 4 percent the first year, 3 percent the next two years; productivity bonuses of 10 percent, 5 percent and 4 percent of annual gross pay; and a boost in the cost-of-living formula from 86 percent of inflation to nearly 100 percent. The offer to engineers, who now make an average of nearly $40,000 a year, called for a 3 percent wage increase and a productivity bonus of 10 percent of gross pay in the first year and no further general increases.
